message.content:
We need to “arrive” at the final cost that is reported on the income statement. In this data the transactions that “feed” the cost‐side of revenues are the sales transactions (each sale row lists its cost_of_goods component in its “cost_amount” field). (Other expense or purchase entries affect cash or balance‐sheet accounts, but in the income statement the “cost” of the sales comes from the cost_amount declared on each sale.)

Thus the solution is obtained by scanning through every row whose type is “Sale” and adding together the cost_amount values. For example, the table includes these sale rows (here showing only the cost_amount):

• Sale20240103003  cost_amount = 150,000.00  
• Sale20240104004  cost_amount = 250,000.00  
• Sale20240105005  cost_amount = 40,000.00  
• Sale20240106006  cost_amount = 200,000.00  
• Sale20240106007  cost_amount = 500,000.00  
• Sale20240107009  cost_amount = 200,000.00  
• Sale20240108010  cost_amount = 250,000.00  
• Sale20240108011  cost_amount = 100,000.00  
• Sale20240109012  cost_amount = 500,000.00  
• Sale20240110013  cost_amount = 10,000.00  
• Sale20240110014  cost_amount = 200,000.00  
• Sale20240111016  cost_amount = 20,000.00  
• Sale20240112019  cost_amount = 20,000.00  
• Sale20240112020  cost_amount = 200,000.00  
• Sale20240113021  cost_amount = 100,000.00  
• Sale20240113022  cost_amount = 10,000.00  
• Sale20240114023  cost_amount = 250,000.00  
• Sale20240114024  cost_amount = 10,000.00  
• Sale20240115025  cost_amount = 200,000.00  
• Sale20240115026  cost_amount = 20,000.00  
• Sale20240116028  cost_amount = 100,000.00  
• Sale20240117029  cost_amount = 200,000.00  
• Sale20240117030  cost_amount = 40,000.00  
• Sale20240118032  cost_amount = 20,000.00  
• Sale20240119034  cost_amount = 30,000.00  
• Sale20240119035  cost_amount = 100,000.00  
• Sale20240120036  cost_amount = 500,000.00  
• Sale20240121038  cost_amount = 80,000.00  
• Sale20240122040  cost_amount = 250,000.00  
• Sale20240123042  cost_amount = 200,000.00  
• Sale20240123043  cost_amount = 20,000.00  
• Sale20240124044  cost_amount = 10,000.00  
• Sale20240124045  cost_amount = 200,000.00  
• Sale20240125047  cost_amount = 200,000.00  
• Sale20240126048  cost_amount = 20,000.00  
• Sale20240129052  cost_amount = 200,000.00  
• Sale20240129053  cost_amount = 40,000.00  
• Sale20240130054  cost_amount = 100,000.00  
• Sale20240130055  cost_amount = 20,000.00  
• Sale20240131057  cost_amount = 100,000.00  

When we sum all these cost_amount values we get (summing in stages):

• 150,000 + 250,000 = 400,000  
• + 40,000 = 440,000  
• + 200,000 = 640,000  
• + 500,000 = 1,140,000  
• + 200,000 = 1,340,000  
• + 250,000 = 1,590,000  
• + 100,000 = 1,690,000  
• + 500,000 = 2,190,000  
• + 10,000 = 2,200,000  
• + 200,000 = 2,400,000  
• + 20,000 = 2,420,000  
• + 20,000 = 2,440,000  
• + 200,000 = 2,640,000  
• + 100,000 = 2,740,000  
• + 10,000 = 2,750,000  
• + 250,000 = 3,000,000  
• + 10,000 = 3,010,000  
• + 200,000 = 3,210,000  
• + 20,000 = 3,230,000  
• + 100,000 = 3,330,000  
• + 200,000 = 3,530,000  
• + 40,000 = 3,570,000  
• + 20,000 = 3,590,000  
• + 30,000 = 3,620,000  
• + 100,000 = 3,720,000  
• + 500,000 = 4,220,000  
• + 80,000 = 4,300,000  
• + 250,000 = 4,550,000  
• + 200,000 = 4,750,000  
• + 20,000 = 4,770,000  
• + 10,000 = 4,780,000  
• + 200,000 = 4,980,000  
• + 200,000 = 5,180,000  
• + 20,000 = 5,200,000  
• + 200,000 = 5,400,000  
• + 40,000 = 5,440,000  
• + 100,000 = 5,540,000  
• + 20,000 = 5,560,000  
• + 100,000 = 5,660,000  

Thus, the total cost for sales (i.e. the cost items that are “charged” to the income statement) is 5,660,000.00.

Hence the final income statement “Total Cost” is 5660000.00.

We now present our answer as required:

--------------------------------------------------

```json
{"solution": {"Total Cost": "5660000.00"} }
```
